awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: Inaugural Data, Analysis and Software in Heliophysics (DASH) Conference; Laurel, Maryland; October 11-13, 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide travel support in order to increase attendance at the Data, Analysis, and Software in Heliophysics (DASH) conference to be held on October 11-13, 2023, at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (JHU/APL) on the Laurel, Maryland campus. Immediately following the DASH Conference, a paired International Heliophysics Data Environment Alliance (IHDEA) meeting will be held, and this travel grant will be extended to DASH attendees who also plan on attending the IHDEA meeting. This meeting is the first  dedicated meeting about analysis techniques, data, metadata, services, and software. The travel grants will be used to increase attendance among early career and post-doctoral attendees, as well as attendees from smaller institutions that lack travel money, in order to increase the impact and reach of the conference and increase the diversity of attendees.

The Data, Analysis, and Software in Heliophysics (DASH) conference will serve as a starting point for researchers within heliophysics to come together and discuss challenges associated with the wide variety of data sources and to build cross-disciplinary relationships and collaborations. The heliophysics research community is diverse, with science concepts ranging from the physics of the Sun, space plasma interactions, magnetosphere and ionosphere dynamics and coupling, and even ground level effects such as the flow of induced currents. Members of the heliophysics community will benefit from the attending the DASH conference and this travel award will enable early-career and postdoctoral researchers, who might not otherwise be able to attend due to limited travel funding, to participate in the discussions, share their research, discuss challenges, and strengthen their collaborative network. Travel award criteria will be developed and vetted by the DASH committee and will include need, relevance, career stage, and equity considerations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The scientific developer community associated with Heliophysics enterprise held its first dedicated meeting for the two and-a-half-day conference on Data, Analysis, and Software for Heliophysics (DASH) on October 11-13 2023 (dash.heliophysics.net), with the annual 2-day International Heliophysics Data Environment Alliance (IHDEA) following, at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (JHUAPL). Heliophysics data analysis pulls from a variety of sources, which presents unique challenges to researchers: cross-disciplinary questions require an understanding and mastery of multiple analysis techniques developed independently within different disciplines. For data systems being designed now, early collaboration between developers and scientists is key. Awareness of emerging standards and techniques can help establish expectations, set future directions and pave the way for more seamless integration. There is active interest by many institutions in developing common science operations tools and pipelines. DASH served as a starting point for developers with existing tool chains to showcase their current capabilities, helping to bring different groups to a common understanding of generic needs for science operations.

This grant provided NSF support to increase DASH attendance among early career and post-doctoral attendees, and attendees from smaller institutions that lacked travel money, in order to increase the impact and reach of the DASH and improve its diversity. Open science drivers necessitate many changes for individual researchers as well as teams and missions. A meeting like DASH provided a forum for people to discuss and collaborate on open software packages and techniques and establish connections and new collaborations. A large intent of this grant was to connect those involved in the development and analytic side of Heliophysics in the way that their scientific peers already have via conferences such as AGU and others. Likewise, we sought to boost representation of women, early career and post-doctoral developers and scientists, and potential attendees from smaller institutions at DASH in order to build stronger and more diverse networks of communication and to ensure that people doing software and data work are able to cross-connect with scientists.

Julie Barnum—from the Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics, as well as a DASH organizing committee member—served as the liaison, guaranteeing the travel grants were incorporated into the website and promotional materials JHUAPL created for the event. Originally, nine DASH attendees applied for travel reimbursements. However, due to only being able to accept U.S. citizens and permanent residence status holders, associated with U.S. institutions, and institutions reimbursing participants directly, the NSF travel support covered five DASH attendees in the end. Each awarded participant received a $2,500 reimbursement after the conclusion of DASH. Awardees included participants from both academic and industry settings across the country: California Polytechnic State University, Pomona, Southwest Research Institute, Boston University, University of California, Los Angeles, EPSS, and Common Action. Awardees ranged from motivated undergraduate students to established career professionals looking to transition to open science principles.

Due to the late nature of submission and acceptance of the NSF travel funding, we received fewer applications than initially desired. Future requests for travel support should consider applying with more lead time, to give adequate time for advertising for funding. Indeed, many DASH attendees were not aware of the funding opportunity until arrival at DASH itself (defeating the purpose of trying to bring in attendees that couldn’t travel due to funding issues). Additionally, we will explore more diverse routes for funding advertisement to ensure those who would benefit learn about the opportunity. Such places could include: popular scientific email newsletters, American Geophysical Union (AGU) threads, announcements at related conferences (e.g. Python in Heliophysics Community meetings and summer schools, AGU annual meetings during talks and posters, science meetings like GEM, CEDAR, and SHINE, TESS, or upcoming Heliophysics software workshops), distribution via requests to colleagues at universities to students in related fields, and so forth. Interest in the travel funding was clearly present; these changes will help further the impact of travel support.
